title: Science Finally Has a Good Idea about Why We Stutter
intro: A glitch in speech initiation gives rise to the repetition that characterizes stuttering.

transcript.author: Karen Hopkin
transcript.text: This is Scientific American’s 60-Second Science. I’m Karen Hopkin.

transcript.author: Hopkin
transcript.text: When you stop to think about it, it’s not all that easy to speak. First you have to think of something to say. Then your brain has to tell your mouth to say it. Interruptions anywhere along this articulation pathway can impair the utterance, and create something like a stutter. Now, studying a neurocomputational model of this complex process, researchers have found that stuttering stems from a glitch in the neural circuit that initiates speech. They presented their findings at the Meeting of the Acoustical Society of America. [F. Guenther et al., Stuttering Starts at Speech Initiation, Not Due to Impaired Motor Skills]

transcript.author: Frank Guenther
transcript.text: My main research interest is translating how the brain translates thoughts ...

transcript.author: Hopkin
transcript.text: Frank Guenther of Boston University.

transcript.author: Guenther
transcript.text: ... into movements of the tongue and the other speech articulators that convey these thoughts to another person.

transcript.author: Hopkin
transcript.text: He says that stuttering is very common and it happens in all languages. It’s estimated that about one percent of the world’s population stutters.

transcript.author: Guenther
transcript.text: Despite this, and despite being studied at least as far back as the ancient Romans, our understanding of what causes stuttering has been until recent years very poor.

transcript.author: Hopkin
transcript.text: Numerous neural circuits come into play when it comes to generating speech. But the key drivers can be broken down into two main circuits.

transcript.author: Guenther
transcript.text: One is an initiation circuit and the other is an articulation circuit. To understand the function of these circuits it’s useful to consider something like the energizer bunny which has an on/off switch as well as a set of motors and gears that make the bunny walk and play drums when the switch is turned on.

transcript.author: Hopkin
transcript.text: The on/off switch initiates the movement. And the motors and gears make it happen. But which of these circuits can lead to a stutter? To find out, Guenther pieced together equations that represent how the neurons that form these circuits interact.

transcript.author: Guenther
transcript.text: These equations describe neural activity in different parts of the brain including the basal ganglia, cerebellum, and the cerebral cortex.

transcript.author: Hopkin
transcript.text: One set of equations represents the electrical activity of the neurons in all of these regions…another the strength of the connections they form with each other. That allows Guenther and his team to experimentally manipulate various aspects of the system.

transcript.author: Guenther
transcript.text: And it allows us to test different versions of the story regarding the basal ganglia’s involvement in stuttering by basically impairing different parts of the circuit and observing what happens in terms of speech output and also brain activity.

transcript.author: Hopkin
transcript.text: The basal ganglia, structures tucked beneath the brain’s cerebral cortex, play a critical role in initiating a variety of motor activities.

transcript.author: Guenther
transcript.text: They basically monitor our thoughts sensations and actions and they determine which actions we should perform next.

transcript.author: Hopkin
transcript.text: That includes the muscles involved in speech. [audio] Good doggie.

transcript.author: Hopkin
transcript.text: That’s an example of the speech that comes from Guenther’s computational model when everything is working as it should. But then Guenther fiddles with the equations in the initiation circuit…reducing the connections here or boosting the stimulation there. Which produces what sounds like a typical stutter. [audio] Guh-g-g-good doggie.

transcript.author: Hopkin
transcript.text: That says to Guenther…

transcript.author: Guenther
transcript.text: …stuttering is a problem with the on/off switch. The motors and gears work fine. But the switch doesn’t always turn on when it should. Or it doesn’t stay on as long as it should. This results in delays in initiating a word. Or repetitions of the first part of the word. [audio] Guh-guh-good doggie.

transcript.author: Guenther
transcript.text: …and these are the behaviors that we refer to as stuttering.

transcript.author: Hopkin
transcript.text: Having a computer model allows Guenther to test out different hypotheses for why the initiation circuit fails…whether, for example, it’s an overabundance of activation or a degradation of neuronal signaling. Guenther says he’d like to combine his model with imaging studies that show the basal ganglia in action…to see whether his predicted mechanisms play a role in people who stutter. The ultimate goal is to come up with precisely targeted treatments…like drugs that tweak the activity of the basal ganglia without inducing serious side effects…

transcript.author: Guenther
transcript.text: Or possibly even implanted electrodes that modulate activity in particular parts of the basal ganglia circuit.

transcript.author: Hopkin
transcript.text: Which should make your basal ganglia as good as that… [audio] … doggie

transcript.author: Hopkin
transcript.text: For Scientific American’s 60-Second Science, I’m Karen Hopkin. [The above text is a transcript of this podcast.]
